name: transfer
body:
# What is this about?

This project is a simple incremental backup script that uses
rsync to transfer files.

Here is an example of how you might call it once:

```bash
transfer -r example.net -s apache <<EOF
/var/www/
/srv/www/
/etc/apache2/
EOF
```
And what it may give you in return:

```
/var/backups/hosts.d/ # the base directory to store backups into
└── example.net       # remote
     └── apache       # subject
         ├── empty    
         ├── err      # failed copies
         ├── ok       # copies that finished correctly
         │   ├── 20120405195300  # date/time
         │   │   ├── data.d      # actuall files
         │   │   ├── start       # start date/time
         │   │   ├── end         # finish date/time
         │   │   ├── subject     # a name like apache or files
         │   │   ├── remote      # remote server hostname
         │   │   ├── local       # backup server hostname
         │   │   ├── rsync.log   # transfer details
         │   │   ├── size        # size of files inside data.d
         │   │   ├── status      # status of this copy (ok or err)
         │   │   ├── uuid        # id
         │   │   ├── previous    # parent id
         │   │   └── version     # version of the script
         │   └── last -> /var/backups/.../ok/20120405195300
         └── tmp      # meanwhile a copy is made
```

# Why should I use it?

Do you need to retain and query information about how a
backup was made but will prefer to not use a database?
 
Maybe you will reallocate copies to other servers but wish
you could known where did it come from?
 
Do not know where to place the files you want to restore
again?
 
Want to save space but wish you don't need to wait for
hours for a reconstruction process when you need some
old files?
 
Must you store things in the filesystem directly for performance,
storage restrictions or easy of access?
 
Absolutely need data stored in backups to be directly explorable
and manipulable because you don't know where that file may be?
 
You wish to construct you own backup policy, create you own reports
or make tools around the process?
 
Hate push backups because you don't want your backups to get
deleted by intruders?
 
transfer is pretty dumb, but can help with a lot of complicated
problems, and it's just around 200 lines of shellscript (maybe half
of that are comments!).
 
Please try, and come to love or hate it.

# How this came to be?

Once upon a time there was a tool created by the local
wizard, him who created the current infrastructure.
 
And for a time, things worked well, and people were
happy.
 
But eventually, he went to explore new lands, leaving
his precious infrastructure for others to guard.
 
And then, there came a problem, nobody understood
his work, and things no longer worked well.
 
With no adequate replacements, dark times ensured.
 
Aberrations started to dwell in the new servers. And
sometimes managed to get in the old ones too.
 
Time passed and things got worse, till a ray of hope
shined in the middle of darkness.
 
A new tool appeared, it was young, but everybody could
understand it.
 
Should we trust that tool?

# How do I get it?

At the top of the page there are download links, I will recommend
to get into the github page.

Check the README and source code. Run it once. Think about it.

# Can I ask a question, contribute a patch or say hi?

Sure, send me an email (check my github profile) or ping me
at twitter (@CarlosAntelo), you can also make a pull request
if you want to.

I will be very happy so just do it.
